Line 87: Line 87:
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, since praying mantises have [[ganglia]] within the whole of their bodies,<ref>http://artemis.austincollege.edu/acad/bio/sgoldsmith/skg_ebe/preying_mantis.htm</ref><ref>http://www.biolbull.org/cgi/content/abstract/69/2/203</ref> with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be sexually viable even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case.{{Who|date=July 2007}}
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, since praying mantises have [[ganglia]] within the whole of their bodies,<ref>http://artemis.austincollege.edu/acad/bio/sgoldsmith/skg_ebe/preying_mantis.htm</ref><ref>http://www.biolbull.org/cgi/content/abstract/69/2/203</ref> with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be sexually viable even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case.{{Who|date=July 2007}}
